The night before (June 12) features the Marchas Populares, a parade of neighborhoods competing with choreographed dances and costumes down Avenida da Liberdade. The entire city celebrates with street parties (especially in Alfama), grilled sardines, and festivities. It's the peak of the Santos Populares celebrations that run throughout June.

The Santos Populares (Popular Saints) festivities continue throughout June. The summer solstice brings the longest days of the year with approximately 15 hours of daylight. The city districts of Alfama, Bairro Alto, and Mouraria are decorated with colorful paper decorations. Street vendors sell grilled sardines, bifanas (pork sandwiches), and caldo verde soup. Street parties with music and dancing continue throughout the month.

Late June sees increasing temperatures and continued festivities winding down after the Santos Populares celebrations. The summer tourism season begins to pick up. Tagus River activities increase, with sailing tours and sunset cruises becoming regular offerings.

High summer with warmer temperatures and long daylight hours. Tourism increases significantly as European summer holidays begin. Excellent time for visits to nearby beaches like Cascais and Costa da Caparica. Sintra becomes particularly busy but remains a must-visit day trip. The city's outdoor dining scene is at its most vibrant in Bairro Alto and along the riverside in Cais do Sodré. Jazz em Agosto festival typically takes place at the Gulbenkian Gardens, featuring international jazz musicians.

August 15th is a national holiday celebrating the Assumption of Mary. Religious processions may take place in certain neighborhoods. Many Lisbon locals leave the city for their own holidays in August, giving parts of the city a quieter feel despite high tourist numbers. Some small family-run restaurants may close for summer holidays.

Peak summer with hot temperatures, occasionally exceeding 35°C (95°F). High tourism season with visitors from around the world. São Jorge Castle and Jerónimos Monastery are particularly popular attractions. The Time Out Market is bustling with food offerings. Visitors often seek air-conditioned museums during the afternoon heat, with outdoor activities taking place in mornings and evenings. Many Lisboetas (Lisbon residents) are away on vacation, especially in the first two weeks.

Perfect late summer weather for outdoor activities and exploring the city without the peak season crowds. Tourism begins to decrease as European summer holidays end, making it an excellent time to visit with good weather but fewer crowds. The University of Lisbon welcomes back students, bringing a renewed energy to the city. Riverside walks along the Tagus remain popular in the mild weather.

ranges.event: Lisbon Under Stars & MOTELx Film Festival
ranges.notes: September brings various cultural events to Lisbon as the autumn cultural season begins. The MOTELx Horror Film Festival takes place in late September at Cinema São Jorge. Various music festivals and outdoor events make use of the excellent weather. The main tourist sites become more accessible with shorter queues.

October 5th is a national holiday commemorating the overthrow of the monarchy and establishment of the Portuguese Republic in 1910. Official ceremonies take place at the Parliament and other governmental buildings. Many museums and cultural sites remain open but with holiday schedules.

The Lisbon Architecture Triennale (in triennale years) features exhibitions, conferences, and events focused on contemporary architecture. DocLisboa, the international documentary film festival, brings documentary films from around the world to venues across the city. Autumn weather brings cooler temperatures to Lisbon, but remains pleasant for city exploration. Perfect time for visiting both indoor and outdoor attractions like the Carmo Convent, São Jorge Castle, and the Botanical Garden. The university areas show beautiful autumn colors. Good month for experiencing Lisbon's diverse culinary scene and wine bars in Bairro Alto and Príncipe Real.

While not a traditional Portuguese celebration, Halloween has gained popularity in recent years, especially among younger people. Some bars and clubs in Bairro Alto and Cais do Sodré host Halloween-themed parties. Shopping centers and some restaurants may have Halloween decorations or special events.

ranges.event: All Saints' Day (Dia de Todos os Santos)
ranges.notes: November 1st is a national holiday when Portuguese families traditionally visit cemeteries to honor deceased relatives. Some businesses may be closed, but many tourist attractions remain open. Traditional sweets associated with this time include Bolo Rei (King Cake), which begins appearing in bakeries.

Full autumn with cooler, occasionally rainy weather. Excellent time for museum visits and indoor cultural activities. The LX Market and other food markets become particularly appealing with seasonal produce on weekends. Traditional tascas with hearty Portuguese dishes offer cozy retreats from the weather. The city's Fado houses provide authentic evening entertainment during this quieter tourism period. Lisbon's famous coffee houses like A Brasileira and Café Nicola become especially inviting during cooler weather.

Lisbon's Christmas celebrations begin in late November with the lighting of the city's Christmas lights. The main Christmas tree is usually placed in Praça do Comércio or Terreiro do Paço. Christmas markets open in various locations including Rossio and Eduardo VII Park, featuring craft stalls, food vendors, and seasonal activities. Christmas shopping begins in earnest on Avenida da Liberdade, Chiado, and in the city's shopping centers like Colombo and Vasco da Gama.

ranges.event: Constitution Day & Immaculate Conception (Dia da Constituição & Imaculada Conceição)
ranges.notes: December 1st (Constitution Day) and December 8th (Immaculate Conception) are public holidays. The December 8th holiday traditionally marks the beginning of the Christmas season for many Portuguese families, when Christmas trees and Nativity scenes are set up in homes. Christmas markets and festivities are in full swing by this time.

The Lisbon Christmas Markets run throughout December. Rossio Square and Eduardo VII Park host festive market stalls, Santa's Grotto, and seasonal activities. The city center is beautifully decorated with Christmas lights. Chiado and Baixa are bustling with Christmas shoppers. Traditional Fado performances may take on a festive character in some venues. The Gulbenkian Foundation and Teatro Nacional São Carlos offer seasonal performances and Christmas concerts.

Christmas Eve is the main celebration day for most Portuguese families. Most businesses close by early afternoon. The Christmas Markets end. Lisbon Cathedral and other churches hold special Midnight Mass services. Restaurants that remain open often require advance reservations for special Christmas Eve dinners, which traditionally feature bacalhau (salt cod) and other fish dishes.

December 25 (Christmas Day) is a public holiday. Most businesses, restaurants, and attractions are closed or operate with limited hours. December 26 is not a public holiday in Portugal, unlike in some other European countries, so many businesses reopen. Traditional Christmas lunch often features roast turkey or goat with Portuguese stuffing.

The period between Christmas and New Year is typically busy with both Portuguese and international visitors. Major museums and attractions are open. Good time for winter sales shopping along Avenida da Liberdade and in Chiado. Traditional music and Fado performances continue in venues throughout Alfama and Bairro Alto.

ranges.event: New Year's Eve (Véspera de Ano Novo)
ranges.notes: New Year's Eve celebrations center around Praça do Comércio with midnight countdown events and fireworks over the Tagus River. Many restaurants offer special fixed-price New Year's Eve menus (advance reservation essential), and hotels host celebration events. Bars and clubs throughout Bairro Alto and Cais do Sodré offer special New Year's parties. The riverside provides a spectacular backdrop for fireworks displays.

spring: Lisbon Book Fair (Late May to June)
Sintra Day Trips (less crowded than summer)
Outdoor café culture begins in Chiado and Príncipe Real
summer: Lisbon Beaches (Costa da Caparica and Cascais)
Evening walks along the riverside in Belém
Outdoor dining in Bairro Alto and LX Factory
autumn: Wine tasting events throughout the city
Autumn Colors at Monsanto Forest Park
Sporting Lisbon or Benfica football matches
winter: Lisbon Christmas Markets (late November to December 23)
Christmas lights throughout Baixa and Chiado
New Year's Eve Celebration in Praça do Comércio
Winter Shopping on Avenida da Liberdade
The Time Out Market Culinary Experience
Fado and Dinner shows in traditional houses
Cozy café culture in historic establishments like A Brasileira

scoreDescription.1: Poor: Unfavorable conditions, extreme weather, overcrowded or very limited activities
scoreDescription.2: Below Average: Less ideal conditions, possibly unpleasant weather or very low/high tourism (business closures)
scoreDescription.3: Average: Standard conditions, typical weather, moderate to low tourism (or cool, wet winter days)
scoreDescription.4: Good: Very favorable conditions, pleasant weather, manageable crowds
scoreDescription.5: Excellent: Perfect conditions, special events, ideal weather, moderate crowds
